content: The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007, also known as the "Gas Price Relief Act," temporarily suspends motor fuel taxes. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends various fuel taxes, reducing them to zero during the suspension period. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends certain fuel taxes, reducing them to zero during the suspension period. This includes taxes on gasoline, diesel fuel, kerosene, and the Leaking Underground Storage Tank Trust Fund tax. Exceptions apply to fuel used in trains, motorboats, and aviation. The suspension period ends when the national average price of unleaded regular gasoline is less than $3.00 per gallon. Maintenance of trust fund deposits is also addressed. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends fuel taxes, reducing them to zero until the national average price of gasoline is less than $3.00 per gallon. Trust fund deposits are maintained. The amendments made by this section take effect upon enactment of the Act. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 temporarily suspends fuel taxes until gasoline prices are below $3.00 per gallon. Amendments take effect upon enactment of the Act, including the repeal of expensing for certain refineries. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends fuel taxes until gas prices are below $3.00 per gallon. The Act includes amendments such as repealing the expensing for certain refineries under Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This repeal results in a transfer of equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund. The Gas Price Relief Act of 2007 suspends fuel taxes until gas prices are below $3.00 per gallon, including the repeal of Section 179C of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This results in transferring the equivalent tax liability to the Highway Trust Fund, with adjustments made based on estimates by the Secretary of the Treasury. The amendments apply to property placed in service after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. SEC. 4. FLOOR STOCK REFUNDS. In General, a tax referred to in section 4081(f)(2) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 imposed on any liquid before the enactment of this Act, held by a dealer for sale, shall be credited or refunded to the taxpayer. Time for Filing Claims requires a claim to be filed within 6 months of the enactment, and a dealer must submit a request for refund or credit to the taxpayer within 3 months. No credit or refund allowed for liquid in retail stocks held for retail sale. Definitions of "dealer" and "held by a dealer" follow section 6412 of the Code, including producers. Rules similar to section 6412 apply. SEC. 5. FLOOR STOCKS TAX. Imposition of Tax: A floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, calculated as the excess of the tax that would be imposed under the Internal Revenue Code if the taxable event occurred on that date. Liability and Payment: The person holding the liquid is liable for the tax, to be paid as prescribed by the Secretary within 6 months of the floor stocks tax date. Definitions: A liquid is considered "held by a person" if title has passed to that person. The floor stocks tax is imposed on taxable liquid held on the floor stocks tax date, with payment due within 6 months. Definitions include what constitutes "held by a person" and "taxable liquid." Exceptions apply for certain exempt uses and fuel held in a vehicle tank. The floor stocks tax does not apply to taxable liquid held for certain uses if a credit or refund is allowable. No tax is imposed on liquid held in a vehicle tank. Additionally, no tax is imposed on liquid held on the floor stocks tax date if the amount does not exceed 2,000 gallons, with exemptions for certain fuels. Exempt fuel held by any person is not considered for the tax imposed by subsection (a) if exempt under subsection (d) or (e). Controlled groups are treated as one person, with the definition based on the controlled group concept in section 1563 of the Code. Under regulations prescribed by the Secretary, principles similar to those in subparagraph (A) apply to a group of persons under common control where one or more are not corporations. All provisions of law applicable to taxes imposed by chapter 31 or 32 apply to floor stock taxes imposed by subsection (a) to the same extent. SEC. 6. GASOLINE PRICE MONITORING. The Federal Trade Commission will monitor gasoline prices in the US, determining the national average price monthly and reporting the results to Congress and the public. The Speaker of the House of Representatives will establish a Commission on Gas Price Relief within three months of this Act. The Commission, comprised of 9 Members, will study the causes of high oil prices and submit a report to the House of Representatives within 1 year. The report will include revenue raisers to replenish the Treasury for any loss resulting from the suspension of Federal excise taxes on motor fuels. The Commission on Gas Price Relief, established by the Speaker of the House of Representatives, will consist of 9 members. The co-chairmen of the Commission will be the Chairman of the Committee on Ways and Means and the Chairman of the Committee on Energy and Commerce. Members will be appointed by various officials, with specific party affiliations requirements.
